comments.commentBody:
I graduated in three years from an undergraduate institution with a lot of debt despite working 20 to 30 hours per week. There were numerous problems that I faced in my attempt to finance my college education. First, I did not attend school in an area of the country where you could get a non-minimum wage job without having a stable schedule. Second, I did not qualify for non-loan federal aid because my parents started making significant money right before I started college. Third, state colleges would save me little money due to the scholarships I received at private institutions.

I will freely admit that had I made a couple of changes my debt load would probably be less. However, there is little to indicate that I could have graduated without any debt or that the debt would be insignificant.

The people that suffered the most were my intelligent peers that could not get the financing together to finish their education. I know a number of very intelligent individuals that incurred thousands of dollars in debt but were unable to finish their education due to tuition increases. I don't have the solution to this problem. However, if we continue to move forward on this trajectory we will see two groups of bright people. The first group is buried under crushing student loan debt. The second is stuck in the lower class because they could not get the education that would allow them to live up to their potential.

Got that, Kids?? If you risk your life fighting in one of Bush's Wars of Convenience and move to an area where you can grow and kill your own food, then you too can graduate debt-free from a Top Ten Regional South University!

In the immortal words of Don King: "Only in America!"

Why do we always focus on how much students must do to meet the unconscionable costs of tuition, board, fees, etc., without ever asking universities to justify their exorbitant costs?

I commend the students portrayed in this article, but not everyone can do what they do. In my case, I graduated high school at 16 and entered a prestigious, private university in NYC. I was from a blue collar family in NYC and the first to attend college. Tuition was paid through merit scholarships and whatever I could earn from p/t work-study and summer jobs; and I lived at home. But it was my ambition to become a professional in the health field, and that meant graduate training. At that point, student loans became a necessity. My studies as well as the required, unpaid training placements took up so much of my time, I could only manage to work occasionally as an adjunct instructor at night. Exhaustion was my most constant companion. Then came repayment of those student loans over 15 years, during which my life choices were severely limited and strained.

I've spent my career helping others, and yet also paying for that privilege. It's ironic that in the 1960's, my grandfather, with an 8th grade education, was able to work and save enough to buy a single family home in Queens. But I, with an advanced graduate degree, living as frugally as possible, will never own any property because what savings I may have had has gone into student loans. So much for the American dream.
What a novel Idea.  Getting ahead through MLM

We have devised a way to help students pay off loans through sales of popular products.  This in conjunction with working on lowering cost which will be easier said than done will help tons of families.

I wonder why this is a story now. This should have been a story ages ago. Even before states balanced their budgets by cutting aid to higher eduation, the ability of people to afford college has been compromised. This was evident when I went back for masters 20+ years ago, colleges were jacking up tuition even as college loans were becoming less advantageous for students. A generation or so ago, someone could work their way through a credible private university--no they can't. And now, even a public institution is a challenge. Like Paul Ryan, I had survivors' benefits to help with my undergrad education. I also worked different low paying jobs and managed to leave without debt. It would be difficult to do that today. It was getting difficult to do that 15 years ago. The real question is not how people are making it (answer: scholarships of GI Bill plus work, and sacrificing a social life), but how we can change all this.

Back in 2000 in California I earned $6 an hour through high school, working at a local feed store. After tax, my income barely covered car expenses - let alone any savings. In college, the only available internship was an hour and half drive away (in sprawling Southern California). My $10 an hour stipend once again barely covered car expenses (driving was the only option, due to the lack of a public transport system), food, rent and the occasional textbook.

Upon reflection, I still have no idea how I could have graduated without debt.

Thank you kindly for sharing your experience.
Many students seem to miss the profound opportunity college genuinely offers besides earning a better living after you've earned a degree.
Quintessentially, approaching college with an open mind, provided you've studied at a well-balanced, interdisciplinary school, will enrich your existence beyond any favorable measure.
Similar to your experience, my undergraduate education was at a small liberal arts college, and my graduate education was also grounded in a pragmatic, strong interdisciplinary environment.
All the best.

I went to a small, private liberal arts college 20 years ago.  I received grants, worked part time, had help from my parents, and took out loans.  I graduated with debt that I am still repaying.  But I wouldn't trade it for anything.  The experiences I had and the lifelong friends I made have been worth every dime.  My parents were definitely not wealthy, but they wanted me to go to college to learn to think critically, to debate new ideas, to discover new passions, and to begin to develop a sense of myself and my place in the world.  I majored in government, but I also studied literature, sociology, writing, several foreign languages, economics and history.  I took classes that were interesting without worrying about how they would get me a job later.  I also had a lot of fun.  College is not just a means to an end.  You have the rest of your life to work.  Consider what you sacrifice when you focus only on the money.

Don't go near NYU. They exist only to make a profit. Educating undergraduate students is at the bottom of their list of things to do.

They may have come up in the world since the 1970s, when all it took to get into NYU was the ability to breathe in and out and write a check for tuition, but don't be fooled by their admission numbers. All it represents is the number of students who would love to come to NYC for college, and have parents who are willing to pay. NYU is a chew them up and spit them out kind of "university."

Other than a nice location in NYC, your child will get a much better education at your flagship State University, than at NYU.

Save your money. Send your kid to the UVa or the U of Michigan, or Wisconsin, or Berkeley. They will get a better education, even if you have to pay out-of-state-tuition, and you can use the money you saved to visit NYC on your own terms.
It's also anecdotal evidence that there's much of a "plight" among older workers at all. See David Blau's entry in this discussion for the evidence.
@Jeo:  Except there's not much evidence there.

You give anecdotal evidence regarding someone learning new skills. But not all are adaptable to new sets of skills, particularly if it involves a different educational area.

Will a laid off middle manager suddenly become skilled in quantitative analysis? Will an accountant become a production supervisor? Sounds good, but not really too well though out.

The republicans talk about "jobs" but they only care about low taxes, low regulation and low levels of transparency. Jobs are an expense. They would never hire anyone unless demand dictated it. Then they would probably "create" those jobs in China.

Where's Cantor's discussion about full employment? That would mitigate deficit and spending problems. Where's discussion of an appropriate mix regulation and free-market behavior? Cantor offers slapping new paint on the GOP regressive's decaying house.

The British Conservative party took a stunning, landslide beating in 1945, putting the Labor Party firmly in power. The Conservatives set up a research committee to study social changes and rethink their policies.

In 1947, they published what they called the Industrial Charter. In it, they offered a concept for being conservative and progressive. It also included a Pledge to Consumers, a Women's Charter, and a Worker's Charter. It was still four years before they returned to power but at least they acknowledged the post-WW II world had changed and they'd accomodate those changes.

The GOP is not going to return to national power, and will start losing state power, until they, too, develop a plan that integrates conservative and progressive. They need to acknowlege women, Americans of color, immigrants, a degree of social safety netting, gay Americans, and universal quality education in every community, such as found in Union City, NJ, (with early childhood education), and emphasis on expanding public technical colleges and universities.

The GOP regressives are on the taxpayers' dime same as everyone else in Congress. It's time GOP regressives start acknowledging change, try to succeed, and try to help our nation prosper.

And remember, initially the National Socialists needed the support of traditional conservatives to gain power, the latter imagining they could use the former to advance their interests.  The would-be users ended up being used.  Sort of like the Republicans using the tea party in 2010, only to find themselves being taken over and strangled.

same here for women writer's intimate observations of men's attributes. I can empathize with their point of view and even cheer on their appetites, but I studiously avoid their books. The merely salacious has little literary merit and stories predicated on heaving bosoms and pulsing appendages are trite and sexist. Cut to the chase and spare me the beefcake. Women are the real prodigious physical specimens anyway, and my psychological interest and admiration is piqued by their plucky leaps out of convention. Thomas Perry's heroine, Jane Whitefield, is my kind of girl.

There is waste in every human endeavor.  Yes, minimizing waste is an admiral goal, but the idea that the presence of any waste invalidates an institution is simple-minded.  If such a standard were applied, there would be NO institutions left.  There is waste at IBM, there is waste in google,  There is waste at the NRA.   Get over it.

Sorry, but you can't infer "all government spending is inefficient" from "some government spending is inefficient."

During the 2008 presidential debates, Obama quoted a figure for wasteful programs that was about 40 billion, to my memory. It would be a nice to see a citation for your claims.
Where, exactly, has Dr. Krugman or any other "theorist" made any such blanket statement?

Completely lost in the discussion of the abstract concept of "government spending" that has no relationship to real world government spending is the total waste, inefficiency, and ineffectiveness of federal spending.
The Government Accounting Office has identified 200 instances where the federal government has multiple programs doing exactly the same thing. Not only are we wasting billions do the same thing twice the GAO found no process of oversight whatsoever in place to judge if those programs we achieving the results and accomplishing the goals of the programs. Talk about the definition of simply throwing money at a problem.
These repetitive programs totaled $200 billion dollars a year.

The GAO says that half of the $64 billion that Congress is spending on IT projects is wasted. The projects are so far behind schedule they will never get completed or accomplish the goals they were funded to accomplish. The GAO recommended that Congress end these programs as soon as possible. This report was given to Congress two years ago. Congress finally followed the GAO's recommendations in the last month. Congress wasted money waiting two years to cut those completely wasted programs. Congress also didn't bother to sue the company that didn't deliver what it was paid to deliver.

The assumption of theorists like Krugman that federal government spending is efficient, effective, and productive is just simply wrong.
Work to vote the Obstruction Party out in 2014!
Martin is right; And Winning Progressive cites the recent history. To reason, I add rage. And a wishful request: where, for those who remember, is Bill Kunstler when we need him?

Have nothing but respect and admiration for those who do this important work. Wish I could do more of helping out with Sandy restoration myself, but do not have enough hours in the day for it. However, you are mistaken, none of you is comforting my kids. It is very insulting and patronizing to assume that all working parents are neglectful parents and freeloaders, and that poor kids of those neglectful parents are in a need of comforting. My children, just like the children of stay-at-home moms, are properly supervised, thank you, both at school and at home. We pull our own weight in carpools and play dates. I still have to meet that stay-at-home mom who has time to watch soap operas, their lives are very busy. Those stereotypes are long gone, but, please, do not stereotype the other way around.

In my personal and extensive legal professional experience with mental health and mental health law issues, I might have a few minor quibbles but you are about 98% right.

I have had privileged and confidential relationships, including but not limited to attorney-client, with the significantly mentally ill daughters, sisters, nieces etc. of politicians of both parties and other prominent personages, most by court appointments. Even when it does happen in such families, they are often in denial. I was at a political function and, meeting a mental illness client's family member incumbent elected official in the receiving line, simply asked him how she was getting along. He reacted as though I had thrown something smelly in his face and hasn't spoken to me since.

I don't know where you live, but I have lived, suffered clinical depression, and practiced law for many years and represented both patients and families who wanted help and couldn't get it for love or money, much less at prices they could afford, as well as others who people had tried to lock up without proper cause, and others who could not see that their behavior was dangerous to themselves and others but were patient-dumped.   Way too many who are not criminals wind up in the penal system.

This article sheds light on families who struggle with a mentally ill loved one, and the helplessness they encounter. An example is when an adult child requires an involuntary hospitalization.  Another resource for this is Mobile Crisis, for a patient who may be decompensating (ie., psychosis) and may pose a danger to himself/others. Mobile Crisis team provides immediate emergency response and determines whether the patient requires hospitalization. This service is available to people of all income levels. Thanks for sharing personal struggles and a sense of hope.

Hypocrisy was rightly mentioned in this analysis. Senator Obama campaigned in 2008 against Bush-era policies that he condemned as antithetical with America's values.

Yet, President Obama continued enforcing most Bush Administration policies and strategies. Gitmo remains open, the war in Afghanistan expanded even after Bin Laden was killed, and we still have a presence in Iraq.

President Obama acts unilaterally, something Bush was critically accused of doing. He talks openly of by-passing Congress in all kinds of matters. We intervened in Libya, Egypt, and we expanded the use of drone strikes with no Congressional input.

Perhaps more troubling are our contradictory polices with respect to intervention. It was acceptable in Libya and Egypt but not in Syria. Mubarak is no exemplar of human rights but he is not Assad. Yet we refuse to help depose Assad while we supported the overthrow of Mubarak; both actions have only further destablized the region.

The hypocrisy arises from President Obama's supporters when they say they say that they trust these policies under Obama and not the man who helped develop them. How petty, partisan, and frankly nonsensical.

President Obama discovered that there is a difference between campaigning and governing. The former only requires winning the minds of a thin majority. The latter requires doing the right thing for all. Sadly, his supporters do not understand or accept this reality.

The complete hypocrisy has never been so stark, has it?
To be clear, I have no problem with my country. I have a huge problem with the people who support this president no matter what he does. Even if what he does goes completely against the things that they listed as their core beliefs.

He's a beautiful looking man. I get it. He's a great celebrity, and his supporters assign the best of intentions to him no matter what he does. He's the football captain and the prom king wrapped up in one. That doesn't make him a good mayor, much less a good president.

What's up with the slightly nasty, snarky tone from the critics?  It's unbecoming and really unnecessary.  These are wonderfully talented people enjoying their night of recognition.  Let's celebrate them guys instead of using your public platform to denigrate them.

I consider myself from the Philadelphia area, but, full disclosure, I lived in Altoona, PA, for a few years, which is the home of Sheetz.

If I am out on the road, and I need gas or am hungry, I will stop at either chain, if there is no Wawa. If there is a Wawa, I'm there...I can't help myself. More than anything, the huge selection of Tastykakes is a big game changer for me.

That said, there are some things that I think the article has missed:

- Over the years, there has been some friendly competition between the two chains, and I think this has benefited both chains in their advance to provide some of the best and cheapest roadside fuel and refreshment in the US.
- I think there was once a gentleman's agreement to stay out of the other chain's territory (whatever that might have been), but that is clearly over, but what the heck, there is plenty of space out there, and plenty of uninitiated people who have something to look forward to.
- I think that everybody has an opinion on what his favorite place is, but there still is a lot of respect for the other chain as well.
- I have lived in the Northern VA area for 30 years, but every time I go to a Wawa, it's like going home. Did I mention Tastykake? Growing up, Tasty Lemon Pie was my favorite. Yeah, they don't make em the way they used to, but it's close enough. And now you can get Tasty Eclairs...there's nothing better...nothing.

Definitely prefer the food at Sheetz to that at Wawa, but I'll get gas in Ephrata wherever it's cheaper (sometimes that's even Turkey Hill!). I wish Sheetz would go national so I could get food everywhere I travel, but at least I live deep in Sheetz territory south of Altoona.

I've been a loyal customer of WaWa ever since I moved from York, PA to Philadelphia, PA in 1974.  No matter which location you go to or what time of day, you can depend on great customer service, friendly staff, fresh coffee and a large array of properly prepared food to choose from.  WaWa's are a neighborhood magnet drawing locals as well as travelers.  People will plan to meet at Wawa as their starting point for the day just because its an identifible icon everyone knows about, like a marker point on a map.  "Meet me at the "Wa" on Rt 352 or in Newtown Square or wherever". They grab a drink, sandwich or snack, sit in the parking lot and chat or take off from there for their next destination.  As far as its name, WaWa is the native american name for a Canada Goose thus the logo on their signs, etc.  Employees truly like and are proud of working for WaWa which no doubtds adds to the friendly atmosphere. Many morning I'll sit in the parking lot with a coffee and breakfast sandwich relaxing and watching all the activity before taking off for work, or stop by for some mac and cheese and a smoothie on my home. I guess it's sort of a calming moment in the day. The Sheetz loyalist are just that only because they haven't been to a WaWa yet.

In most counties banks are regulated and required to have adequate reserves, which are a function of loans outstanding, deposits, and capital, as well as of other factors. When presented the opportunity to lend to even the most credit-worthy borrower the bank must decline the loan if its reserves are inadequate to support it.

Excess reserves are those in excess of requirements (set for all practical purposes by the FED). When holders of wealth perceive that few investment opportunities offer a satisfactory real return, they deposit money in banks which, unless they find suitable borrowers, will report reserves far in excess of requirements.

This condition drives down interest rates, and can even lead banks, as well as other holders of money (like investment bankers, hedge funds, and insurance companies), to lend imprudently, or to invest in novel derivatives that turn out to be far less creditworthy than the lenders thought. Enough of that can result in widespread massive defaults that lead to a severe recession, a precipitous drop in demand, and a dearth of promising investments leading to high excess reserves.
